instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM Upgrade
threads.message: I have this customer that is asking me to upgrade the ram on his <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook, I have a motherboard of the same model (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with 16 GB, can I change them to his actual mother board? Can this be done? Do I have to remember the position of every chip or is it the same if I just reball the memory chips in any order? Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM Upgrade
threads.message:
Is really worth to such job?
Consider the risk to kill the board.
Some change may be needed, with RAM configuration resistors.
